newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Plane drops fuel tanks over Karachi, seven killed.
newsitem.headline: Plane drops fuel tanks over Karachi, seven killed.

text.p: A Pakistan Air Force jet jettisoned its fuel tanks over a residential area of Karachi on Thursday, setting off a fire that killed at least seven people and injured six, police said.
The pilot of the Mirage fighter, which landed safely at an air force base, dumped the tanks after the plane developed engine trouble on a routine training flight, a military spokesman said.
"There was an engine fault in the plane and the pilot was forced to eject the fuel tanks to make a safe landing," he said.
Witnesses said fire broke out when one of the fuel tanks fell on Gharibabad, a heavily populated residential area in Karachi's District Central.
"There was a loud explosion... I thought a bomb had exploded," said teenager Rashid, who lives nearby. "When I came out I saw neighbouring houses in a blaze."
An air force statement said the pilot had to jettison tanks to save the plane from crashing on a populated area that would have caused a major catastrophe. It said an inquiry had been ordered.

Police said seven people, including a child, died in the blaze. A police official earlier said four children had died, while a spokesman for the Sattar Edhi Ambulance Services said he believed at least 10 people were killed.
Doctors said most of the injured were in a critical condition with 50 to 60 percent burns.
Deputy Superintendent of Police Khawja Nisar said only one of the tanks had exploded. The second tank caused only minor injuries.
"We were lucky that the incident occurred early in the morning," he said. "Casualties could have been much higher if shops were open and there had been traffic on the road."
